billsco

I have an occasional robin visit my lawn this fall, looking for a meager meal before continuing on its way south for the winter.
 
 It lands on the grass and stands tall and still, then bounds three times in a certain direction, stops and then repeats the process. I've read they feel for the telltale vibration of earthworms.
 
 My question involves how they walk. Most birds, rather than put one foot in front of the other, bound like a kangaroo. There are exceptions: ducks waddle, so do pigeons I believe, but most birds bound. 
 
 Has anyone proposed that T-Rex may have done the same? Is there anything in studying their bones to allow for an answer to this? Any preserved footprints? Could all the campy movies have it wrong?
 
 Sorry if these are stupid questions.
Tastyfish
I think it would make more sense to look at the larger birds whne considering the big therapods - an ostrich moves in quite a different from a robin
johnhanks

I have an occasional robin visit my lawn this fall, looking for a meager meal before continuing on its way south for the winter.
 
 It lands on the grass and stands tall and still, then bounds three times in a certain direction, stops and then repeats the process. I've read they feel for the telltale vibration of earthworms.
 
 My question involves how they walk. Most birds, rather than put one foot in front of the other, bound like a kangaroo. There are exceptions: ducks waddle, so do pigeons I believe, but most birds bound. 
 
 Has anyone proposed that T-Rex may have done the same? Is there anything in studying their bones to allow for an answer to this? Any preserved footprints? Could all the campy movies have it wrong?
 
 Sorry if these are stupid questions.

 
 I assume you're talking about the American robin, Turdus migratorius. The European robin, Erithacus rubecula, also bounds rather than walks: presumably that, plus the red breast (orange in your case?) led to the initial confusion.
 
 The muscle attachments of T. rex leg bones, together with measurements of stride length (there's a clue) strongly suggest it didn't hop.
 
 We all ask stupid questions. Please be as tolerant of mine.
billsco

Turdus? Can we say that on this forum?
 
 Yes, our robins over here have orange breasts. An old wive's tale used to explain how the breasts were that color: robins were busy delivering water to babies in hell. Someone finally began asking what babies were doing in hell and the story has been slowing dying since.

pandion

We have found fossilized t-rex footprints. They put one foot in front of the other, just like we do.
Technically, I think it would be more accurate to say that we have found fossilized footprints that may have been made by a t-rex, or were probably made by a t-rex. Just like in the Paluxy River in Texas. The tracks there are thought to be made by a species of Acrocanthosaurus, a species of Pleurocoelus, and an Iguanodon. Fossils of all three have been found in strata of similar age in both Texas and Oklahoma. However, we can't exclude the possibility that the tracks were made by some organisms from which we haven't found a fossil record.
 
 Isn't it funny that Dinosaur Valley State Park has two "life size" models of dinosaurs; one is a "brontosaurus" donated by the Sinclair Oil Company, the other is a horrible model of a t-rex.
 
 Edit: I forgot. The tracks in the paluxy indicate that the theropod walked one foot in front of the other. No indication of hopping at all.
 
 I also notice that hopping is not necessarily a characteristic of birds. Even flighted birds walk. Around here we have grackles that I have never seen hop. Sparrows hop, doves don't. And of course, egrets and herons definitely don't hop. I've never seen a barn swallow on the ground, but I think that mockingbirds do both.
billsco

All right then. I guess I'm a bit relieved to know T-Rex could chase its dinner down like any good terrifying predator should. I was imagining it bouncing around after some hapless prehistoric creature and I couldn't get that mechanical spring sound out of my head.
doG

All right then. I guess I'm a bit relieved to know T-Rex could chase its dinner down like any good terrifying predator should. I was imagining it bouncing around after some hapless prehistoric creature and I couldn't get that mechanical spring sound out of my head.

 Some theorize that T-Rex was actually a scavenger that didn't chase anything down because it had a very large area in the brain for processing odors.

Some theorize that T-Rex was actually a scavenger that didn't chase anything down because it had a very large area in the brain for processing odors.

 
 Well that's interesting. I hadn't heard of that.
 
 Are there any other clues to suggest this dinosaur was a scavenger?
 
 I was surprised to learn that most birds have a poor sense of smell, except for the scavenger birds. They instead rely a good deal on their sight.

OccamsRazor

Well that's interesting. I hadn't heard of that.
 
 Are there any other clues to suggest this dinosaur was a scavenger?

 
 Well, the biomechanical side of things suggest that a frightened human could probably outrun a T-rex style beastie:
 
 http://tam.cornell.edu/students/garcia/.trex_www/naturepaper.html
 
 Which doesn't mean it wasn't an "active" predator in relative terms- it only needed to be quicker than its prey and comparisons of speed with things from the present day are only of use for making Jurassic Park look silly.
 
 
I was surprised to learn that most birds have a poor sense of smell, except for the scavenger birds. They instead rely a good deal on their sight.

 
 T-Rex and its immediate relatives did have their eyes positioned in such a way as to suggest they had a stereoscopic vision (like humans do) and hence good depth perception. This could be read that the animal hunted live prey at least some of the time, although it tells us nothing of the visual actuity those eyes afforded.
billsco

You know, I've been feeling bad about the loss in the value of stock in T. rex. Going from a ferocious flesh-tearing predator to an ambling carion-eater. But I realize we don't need to color the picture for its sake. It was what it was--the most fascinating creature to have ever lived.
prschuster

 Walking-fish:
 Actually, the most fascinating creatures in the whole world are humans. 
 They can climb up trees or swim upstream.
 Or they can walk on the ground or domesticate hounds.
 They can feed on meat or have veggies to eat.
 They know how to talk and how to run, skip & walk.
 They work every day then they come home to play.
 They can walk on two legs or eat ham & green eggs...
